Chapter on Chanda and Others Returning, Part 2
King Åšuddhodana said again:
I now wish in my heart that the world-protecting devas in the four directions, who protect all beings, will now assist my son to accomplish benefit.

Indra, the lord of the devas with a thousand eyes, the husband of ÅšacÄ«, the powerful king, and the devas surrounding him on the left and right, I wish they will assist my son in all his aspirations.
Moreover, the devas in the world, the wind devas, water devas, fire devas, earth devas, in the four directions and the four intermediate directions, may all those devas assist him.
You, the most excellent one, the unsurpassed hero, why do you abandon the four continents?
'My son, now abandoning the family, aspires for the unsurpassed supreme and wonderful fruit of sagehood. May he quickly accomplish the path of supreme perfect enlightenment and realize it early.'
King Åšuddhodana lay on the ground and reproached Kaá¹‡á¹­haka with various words, saying:
'You good horse, in the past you have done many things that I love;
Why is it that today you suddenly do not benefit, but harm the ÅšÄkya family in this way?
My prince always loved you, his mind was in accord with mine, and he always brought joy. Now you are like this, you must cover up and destroy.

You should take me to where the prince is. I will accompany my beloved son and practice austerities together. Now that I am separated from my beloved son, my life is fleeting and I will not live long.'
And he spoke a verse, saying:
'Kanthaka, you horse, go quickly, take me there and come back.
I have no son, so my life is difficult to live, like a seriously ill person without a doctor.'

At that time, King Åšuddhodana, having said these words, out of love for his son, afflicted with pain, lay on the ground, experiencing such suffering and distress, raising his voice and crying out loudly, sometimes falling down and getting up again, his voice choked with emotion.

At that time, there was a wise great minister and a brÄhman national preceptor who saw King Åšuddhodana rolling on the ground, falling to the left and supported on the right, his heart greatly distressed, suffering with grief, his mind bound and constrained, not joyful for a moment, his body and mind simultaneously experiencing great heat and distress.
They wished to relieve the king's mind, so they pretended to have no sorrowful expression and said to the king together:
'Great King!

Now, you should abandon all worries, sorrows, and afflictions, and concentrate your mind. You should think of yourself as strong and not like this, fainting and beating yourself, like an ordinary person crying and shedding tears.
Why is it so?
Great King!
You should know!
In the past, there were many kings who abandoned their royal status like withered flower garlands and turned their backs to enter the mountains.
Moreover, Great King, Prince SiddhÄrtha's past karma was to receive such retribution.
Great King!
Now, you should remember the prediction made by the sage AÅ›ita in the past. He said to the Great King:
That child cannot be detained with the rewards of humans and gods, or with the position of a wheel-turning sage king, to make him temporarily dwell in the world out of greed and love.
Great King!
If you now definitely want to call the prince back, just order the two of us to go, and we will follow the king's order without daring to disobey.
King Åšuddhodana replied to them, saying:
You two, if you know the time, quickly go to the prince's side. If not, my life now has no auspiciousness and is bound by suffering and distress.

At that time, the great ministers and the brÄhmaá¹‡as, the royal preceptors, having heard King Åšuddhodana's instructions like this, immediately set out together and went to where the prince was. They spoke a verse, saying:
The prince should accept such karma. The king should remember the words of SiddhÄrtha in the past.
He recorded that he did not covet the heavenly wheel-turning [kingship], but rather enjoyed the five desires of the human realm.

At that time, the great ministers and the royal preceptors, having spoken these words, went together. As for the horse Kaá¹‡á¹­haka, hearing the above severe reprimands everywhere, his mind was very sorrowful and he gave rise to great heat and distress.
Because of the heat and distress, there was no temporary joy;ğŸ”½...
His mind was not joyful, and so he immediately passed away.
After his life ended, he was immediately reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.

After being born in that heaven, he later knew that the TathÄgata had attained enlightenment, and then descended from that heaven to be born in the country of MadhyadeÅ›a, in the city of NÄbhÄ. In that city, there was a brahmin family that practiced the six dharmas. He became the son of that family, and gradually grew up to be by the side of the TathÄgata.

The TathÄgata knew that in the past he had been a horse, and after his life ended, he was reborn in the heavens. At that time, the Buddha spoke of the causes and conditions of that horse. After hearing the Dharma, he exhausted his defilements, attained liberation, and entered parinirvÄá¹‡a.

At that time, the prince personally took a knife, cut off the topknot on his head, shaved off his beard and hair, put on a kÄá¹£Äya robe, and immediately countless hundreds of thousands of devas were overjoyed, their bodies filled with bliss, unable to contain themselves, with joyful minds, they all let out cries, sang loudly, played with their clothes, and shouted with their mouths, saying:
'Prince Siddhartha!
Now he has left home.
Prince Siddhartha!
Now he has left home.

He will definitely attain supreme perfect enlightenment. Having attained it, all beings subject to birth will attain liberation from those birth-and-death cycles. Even those beings who should experience suffering and separation will all attain liberation from these bonds.'
At that time, at the place where the Bodhisattva cut off his topknot, a stupa was later built called the Topknot Stupa;
Wherever the Bodhisattva wore the kasaya, a stupa was later erected called the Kasaya Receiving Stupa;
Where Channa and Kanthaka said goodbye and returned to the palace, a stupa was later erected called the Channa and Kanthaka Returning Stupa.
As the Bodhisattva walked, he looked ahead and proceeded slowly. When asked by someone, he remained silent and did not reply.
Those people said to each other:
This sage must be the son of the Shakya clan.
Because of this, he came to be called Shakyamuni.
At that time, the Bodhisattva gave rise to this thought in his mind:

'Now that I have already abandoned the royal position, renounced my own retinue, territory, country, and city, I should not give rise to regret. This matter has been accomplished, and it is a dharma of extinction.'
Having had this thought, his mind became even more courageous.

At that time, the Bodhisattva gradually left the village of Animiyaka and was about to head towards Vaishali. On the way, there was a hermitage of a sage. The old sage was named Vakkula (meaning Potter).

When the Bodhisattva entered the sage's abode, his radiance illuminated the mountains and forests. The Bodhisattva removed all his necklaces and also discarded all his Kasi clothes. Just with his own majestic body, he still emitted light, shining on the eyes of the sages in the mountains and forests.
There is a verse that goes:
The Bodhisattva, like an elephant king or a lion, removed his wonderful clothes and necklaces,
And just wore the coarse Dharma robes, his body still shining brightly on those sages.

At that time, in the forest, all the Brahmins and sages who upheld the practices, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, or holding things in their hands, remained in their dignified manner.
All of them, facing the Bodhisattva, gave rise to a respectful mind, loving and respecting him, or they looked up at the Bodhisattva with doubt.

However, in the forest, there were some old brÄhman sages who either picked flowers, fruits, medicinal trees, or grasses and roots. Those who had not yet gathered, having not seen him, did not give rise to doubt. But they quickly heard the sound of the Bodhisattva from afar. Having heard the sound, their minds were startled and they quickly returned to their original dwelling place in the forest.

What should be done, they did not do again. What should be taken, they also did not take again. The remaining flowers, fruits, medicinal herbs, and grass roots, even if already taken, they all abandoned them, but their minds quickly wanted to come before the Bodhisattva.

At that time, all the birds in the forest, namely geese, cranes, ducks, parrots, myna birds, mandarin ducks, avadavats, peacocks, kalaviá¹…ka birds, cuckoos, and so forth, when they saw the Bodhisattva enter the forest, each emitted their own harmonious sounds, making subtle and wonderful sounds.
Moreover, all the insects and animals in the forest, they all abandoned water and grass, not eating or drinking, joyfully coming to the front of the Bodhisattva.
At that time, the brahmins in the forest, for the sake of the sacrifice, milked the cows, taking their milk.
Those cows, although they had been milked, their milk still flowed down naturally as before.
At that time, all those brahmins said to each other:
'We have heard of the eight Vasus, could this person not be one of them?
Some said:
'Among the Rohini stars, this is one of them.
Why is it so?
Since then, entering this forest, the forest emits light, all shining brightly, like the sun first rising to illuminate the world.'
And spoke a verse, saying:
'Either the eighth Pavasani or one of the two Rohini stars,
If not this forest, why is it radiant, like the sun first illuminating the world.'

At that time, those Brahmins who practiced austerities and lived in the forest, according to the offerings produced by the forest, took these offerings and invited the Bodhisattva, each with a sincere mind, bowing their heads to his feet, and said together:
'Welcome, Holy One!
We sages wish to invite the Sage to stay in this place. The flowers, fruits, trees, forests, herbs, roots, leaves, flowing springs, and cold water here are suitable for your use at any time.
This was the dwelling place of ancient sages. If you seek liberation, it is easy to find peace of mind here. This place is empty and quiet, suitable for walking meditation.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva spoke with subtle and beautiful words, with a deep and majestic voice like thunder, and asked about their well-being in a way that was suitable for them.
At that time, there was a brÄhman sage among the sages who was skilled in the methods of forest asceticism. Seeing the Bodhisattva's handsome appearance, he told another brÄhman:
'Do you know, sir?
This celestial youth thoroughly understands the human mind and is skilled in skillful means.
Why is it so?
Common people in the world each say to each other:
I have given birth to children, and I should raise them. When the children grow up, they will be able to support the family for me, engage in commerce to seek wealth, and make a living.
At that time, I will seek wisdom and the Way. If I owe debts to others, I will repay them all.
Thinking like this, because of all the affection and love, he raises the children.
This is not so, seeking the Way for others, not caring about one's own death, not seeking one's own benefit.'
At that time, in the assembly, there was another brÄhman who said to the brÄhman who had spoken before:
'Sir, sir!
It is just as you have said.

The people in the world do not realize this by themselves, do not discern it by themselves, are always discontented, and only say, I need to do such and such now, and tomorrow they will need to do such and such again. They say, When I practice the Dharma, I have not yet reached it.
In this way, all worldly people, due to delusion, not only fail to discern their own self-benefit in this world, but also fail to accomplish any benefits in the future world.'
At that time, when the Bodhisattva descended from Tuá¹£ita Heaven and entered the womb of the ÅšÄkya clan, wishing to be born,
first, in the dwelling place of the sage BhÄrgava, two golden trees spontaneously welled up.
At that time, those two trees were tall and large. On the night when the Bodhisattva renounced the householder's life, they suddenly disappeared into the ground and were completely unseen.
When the sage BhÄrgava saw that the two trees disappeared together that night and were no longer visible, he was greatly distressed, hung his head low, and thought to himself:
'Is it that the signs of my decline have arrived, or are there other evil signs coming?'
The Bodhisattva saw that the sage BhÄrgava was like this, sorrowful, with his head lowered, dejected, and unhappy. He gradually approached him and said to the sage:
'Venerable One!
Why do you have a sorrowful expression, sitting with your head lowered?'
At that time, the sage replied to the Bodhisattva:
'Divine and virtuous youth!
In this dwelling place of mine, for a long time there have been two golden trees that emerged from the ground. Those trees are tall and majestic, and they are delightful to behold.

I see that those trees have suddenly disappeared now. Because they have sunk into the ground, I am now sorrowful, with an unhappy mind. I am sitting here with my head lowered, contemplating like this.'
The Bodhisattva then asked the sage:
'Venerable One!
How long has it been since those two trees emerged?'
The sage replied:
'Up to now, it has been twenty-nine years.'
The Bodhisattva asked again:
'How long has it been since those trees disappeared?'
The sage replied:
'At midnight last night, they suddenly disappeared.'
The Bodhisattva then said to the sage:
'Those two trees grew because of my power and karmic retribution. If I were to become a wheel-turning sage king, I would make this place a well-landscaped garden;
But now that I have renounced home, that is why the trees disappeared last night.
For this reason, Venerable One!
Do not be sad.'

At that time, the Bodhisattva, surrounded by all the sages on the left and right, proceeded to their dwelling place. He wandered as he pleased, observing the various places where he sat, stood, practiced austerities, and diligently sought the path.
At that time, there was a sage in the forest who always practiced austerities, following behind the Bodhisattva.

At that time, the Bodhisattva entered the forest, went to the place where the sages lived, and looked to the east, west, south, and north, observing the places where they practiced austerities while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, wishing to find the most excellent place. He asked the sages, saying:
'I have just entered this path and have not practiced for long, so I wish to ask the sages:
Please explain to me according to the Dharma.
I have not known this Dharma practice of yours.
Please demonstrate and proclaim it for me, so that I may hear it and practice according to the Dharma.
I seek true practitioners who benefit others in this place, and I will also practice according to your austerities.'
Those sages replied to the Bodhisattva, saying:
'You ask us about all the ascetic practices and the Dharma we seek. We will explain them to you in order.

As for the ascetic practices, in this assembly, some eat vegetables, some eat grass tips, some eat the branches of nyagrodha trees, some eat the branches of udumbara trees, some eat the branches of khani trees, and some only eat the branches of one tree.
Some eat cow dung, some eat hemp dregs and various fruit lotus roots, some eat the soft branches of various trees, and some drink water to sustain their lives.
Some live like dung beetles, and some live like deer eating grass to sustain their lives.
Some stand on the ground to feel content, some sit on the ground to feel comfortable, and some eat four mouthfuls of food to sustain their lives.

Some wore clothes made of hemp, some of black sheep's wool, some of grass, some of wild silkworm floss, some of dragon beard grass, some of reeds, some of deer skin, some of old tattered leather, some of disheveled hair, some of felt, some of clothes made of dead people's banners, and some of discarded rags.
Some went naked, slept on thorns, on wooden boards, on stumps, or on pestles.
Some lived in charnel grounds, some in anthills like snakes, some in the open air, and some entered the water.
Some served fire, some turned with the sun.
Some raised their hands, stood still, some squatted on the ground, some did not wash or comb their hair, and their bodies were covered in dust.
Some had topknots, some pulled out their hair, and some pulled out their beards.
However, we of this sort maintain ourselves through such practices, and then sometimes contemplate and practice accordingly.
Or we wish to be reborn in the heavens, or we wish to be reborn among humans, and because of our ascetic practices, we then attain bodily peace and happiness.
Why is this so?
Seeking the Dharma is extremely difficult, and it is necessary to cultivate ascetic practices as the foundation.
He spoke in verse:
Thus, when practicing ascetic practices, there are already rewards of the Thirty-three Heavens,
After ascetic practice and diligence, one attains happiness, therefore, suffering is the cause of all happiness.

At that time, although the Bodhisattva heard the ascetics' ascetic practices like this, his eyes had not yet seen the ultimate of their Dharma, his mind was not pleased, and he knew that these words were not yet true and good. He replied to the ascetics in a slow voice:
'I now observe that although your Dharma has something, suffering must be extinguished, and after that, the karmic retribution goes nowhere else, but only to be reborn in the heavens.

Moreover, all the heavenly palaces and their karmic retribution are impermanent dharmas. Because of practicing such little karmic retribution as above, this kind of ascetic practice must be abandoned, and one also leaves behind all worldly pleasures, practices austerities, and stays far away from all pleasures. In order to seek pleasure, one then enters a great prison again.'
And he spoke a verse, saying:
'You abandon loved ones and worldly pleasures, practice austerities and wish to be reborn in the heavens,
Although you say this is liberation, you do not realize that in the future you will return and enter prison.'
At that time, after the Bodhisattva spoke this verse, he further said:

'If there are people whose bodies are afflicted by suffering, who aspire to a superior state and wish to be reborn in the heavens, because they enjoy the five desires and pleasures of the heavens, they do not know how to be detached, and in future lives, they will not escape the harm caused by afflictions.
Those ascetics!

Because of their ascetic practices, they still seek great suffering. When the lives of those beings end, they see great fear, and therefore seek a good rebirth. Because they seek rebirth, they still do not escape impermanence.
Why is this?

Where in the world are there fears? They still become attached to those places. Because they are severely afflicted by suffering in this world, they seek to be reborn in the heavens to experience pleasure. They long for and aspire to be reborn there. Their tasks are not yet accomplished, and they will fall back into places of no benefit. They also do not seek to be detached from ascetic practices, nor do they seek to be detached from the Dharma of the suffering body. They wish to find a superior place that surpasses the pleasures of the heavens.'
If there are wise people who leave these five desires, they should gradually seek higher and better places, like taking a step forward, to realize a better place, and then seek even better than that.
If one attains the Dharma by tormenting the body, this Dharma of tormenting the body is called non-Dharma.
If one attains happiness in the heavens by tormenting the body, then the Dharma of causal practice attains non-Dharma.
But this body moves because of the mind, therefore one should first regulate the mind and not torment the body.'
And he spoke a verse, saying:
'When this body moves, it turns because of the mind, one should first regulate the mind and not torment the body.
The body is like wood and stone, without knowledge, why should one follow the mind and exhaust the body?'
At that time the Bodhisattva further said:
'If what was said before is that by fasting one will attain blessings, then wild animals should attain great blessings.

Moreover, poor people, due to the shallowness of their past karmic fruits and not planting deeply, have few resources, just like people in the world who lack merit, always seeking the meritorious waters of all spirits on the ground, to bathe their bodies, hoping to obtain as they wish, but it is not so.
' At that time, those ascetic masters said to the Bodhisattva:
'Wise and benevolent one!
What kind of problems do you see here?'
The Bodhisattva replied to those ascetic masters:
'You now practice these ascetic acts, and later return to enter this realm of existence.'
The ascetic masters then further discussed and asked the Bodhisattva:
'We have such Dharma practices here.'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'How can you know that such ascetic practices will return to enter the realm of existence?
Your practice is not the ultimate entry, not a place of fearlessness.'
Then the ascetic teacher again earnestly said to the Bodhisattva:
'Great Virtuous One!
Please do not speak like this.

This place where I dwell and the path I take are places of fearlessness. They have great merit. If a person relies on this path to practice, they can abandon this evil form and attain a supreme and wonderful body.'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'Although one may abandon an evil form and later attain a wonderful body, it is still not a Dharma of leaving existence.
Because of this suffering of the body now, one attains a later body, but that later body is also not free from suffering.
Why is this so?
Although one may practice many kinds of austerities, hoping to seek happiness, one is not free from suffering.
' The ascetic teacher again grasped the principle and said to the Bodhisattva:
'Virtuous One, it is not so. One does not still attain suffering after practicing austerities. It is only because we torment this body that we will definitely attain happiness in the next world.
The Bodhisattva replied:
Such words are also ignorant.
Why is it so?
It is like a person who seeks profit but does not know that there is a great loss within.
Because of knowing the loss, one who seeks profit is not a wise person.
At that time, there was a Brahmin in the assembly who shouted loudly, saying:
How rare!
This prince is truly wise.
It is like a person who obtains delicious food mixed with poison. Who would enjoy eating it?
In this way, although one may obtain happiness later, one has not yet escaped the conditioned phenomena of birth, old age, sickness, and death. Isn't this seeking rebirth again?
At that time, the Bodhisattva said again:
The world of suffering and suffering, hating the ghost of death, and seeking rebirth again, this is great foolishness.ğŸ”½The ascetic said:
Good man,
'Excellent, Prince!

Be careful not to deeply contemplate this practice. This practice was practiced by countless great virtuous ones in the past. This dwelling place was where countless kings and sages in the past, millions and billions of them, practiced these austerities, seeking happiness in the afterlife.
' The Bodhisattva said again:
'As you now say, for millions of years, this is a great delusion!
Alas, this is a lie!

Here, the virtuous ones, because of their austerities, distinguish realms and seek happiness in the afterlife. In the future, they experience the existence of birth and death, never knowing contentment. Within afflictions, they do not do what should be done, and revolve within them. Because they seek happiness in the world, they instead obtain much suffering.'
At that time, the ascetic teacher said again:
'Virtuous Prince!
The lord of this realm, in the city of JÄ«vatindu, the king wishes to hold an unrestricted assembly, to make offerings to the gods, killing many beings, seeking happiness in the afterlife.
The Bodhisattva said again:
'Can killing and harming be called practice?'
The ascetic teacher said again:
'Our ancestors have passed down the method of making offerings to the gods in this way.
' The Bodhisattva replied:
'How can harming others be called the Dharma?ğŸ”½If one's body is covered in dust, can one wipe it off with more dust and become clean?
If one's body is covered in blood, can one wash it off with more blood and become clean?
It is impossible to attain the Dharma by practicing non-Dharma.'
The ascetic teacher said:
'There is such a possibility.'
The Bodhisattva said again:
'What is the reason?'
The ascetic teacher said:
'Based on the Vedas, it is said by the sages.'
The Bodhisattva said again:
'What does this mean?'
The ascetic said:
'If there are people who make sacrifices to the gods, this is called the Dharma.'
The Bodhisattva said again:

'I will ask you about the worldly practices. If someone kills a sheep and makes sacrifices to the gods, and it becomes a Dharma, why don't they kill their beloved relatives and make sacrifices to the gods?
Therefore, I know that killing sheep for sacrifice has no merit.
Your mixed practices are like this in intention.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva saw from a distance, not far from where he was sitting, a clump of trees like a charnel ground. Having seen this, he said to the ascetic masters:
'Venerable ones, just look at that place. What kind of practice is it called?
Under that forest, there are dead bodies being eaten by birds;
Some dead bodies are white bones that have gathered, which can be seen now.
Some dead bodies are burned by fire, forming a pile of bones;
Some dead bodies are hung on trees;
Some dead bodies are killed by their relatives, adorn their seats, and bury them according to the Dharma, later feeling ashamed.
Some dead bodies are surrounded by relatives, escorting them to the charnel ground, placing them on the ground, and returning home.
The ascetic teacher said again:
'Good man, prince!
However, that place, the charnel ground, is common to all four groups, without discrimination, a place of equal giving of the body, a land of blessings and virtues, called the wilderness.
In this place, those who give their bodies do not need to suffer, but quickly attain rebirth in the heavens, seeking the supreme place in the world, quickly attaining happiness.'
Some kind ones threw themselves off cliffs, burned themselves, or gave themselves away, and were reborn in the heavens.
The Bodhisattva said again:
If one practices and acts like this, and later seeks wealth and nobility, alas, how greatly deluded!
Alas, impermanence!
And yet seeking the next world, there are many resentments and enmities, seeking wealth and nobility in the next life, alas, how greatly suffering!
Returning to seek great suffering!
Those foolish and ignorant people enter a great mass of fire, enter the mouth of a great snake.
In this way, with the tongue of eloquence, the Bodhisattva spoke words of liberation to the sages, spoke subtle words, and when he spoke like this, the sun was about to set.
At that time, the Bodhisattva returned to where the sages lived, stayed overnight, and the next day at dawn, he went to another place.
Those sages followed behind the Bodhisattva, going in order.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had walked for a while, he saw those sages following behind him.
Having seen this, he then sat down under a tree, and those sages surrounded the Bodhisattva, some sitting and some standing.
At that time, among those sages, the oldest sage felt a sense of wonder towards the Bodhisattva and said to him:
'O Prince!
Since you came to where I dwell, that place has been adorned by itself.
When you leave, that place will now become a wilderness. For this reason, I only wish that you, O Virtuous One!
Do not abandon the place where I sit.
Why is it so?
If a person wishes to quickly be reborn in the heavens, one who practices in this blessed land will soon be reborn in the heavens.
Therefore, O Virtuous One!
You should not abandon this kind of subtle, pure practice of the ancient sages and go elsewhere.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
You came to my forest with majestic virtue, but now you leave and it suddenly becomes a wilderness.
Therefore, you should not abandon me, just as a person who loves life should not abandon their body.
At that time, after the sages spoke this verse, they further said, 'Good man, prince!
Now that you are here, do you not see any ungrateful and contemptible people?
Or do you see people who have fallen into mixed conduct, or people who engage in impure practices?
If it is not like this, why does the good man not enjoy staying in my dwelling place?'ğŸ”½At that time, the sages spoke this verse and further said, 'Good man, prince!

We immortals wish to follow you as good friends, to comply and not go against, to respectfully follow your teachings and practices, to seek a supreme and wonderful place together with you. Even if we were to live with Jupiter, we would still attain a superior place, let alone us ascetics.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, having received the request from the leaders of the immortals to seek liberation together, seeing their intentions, immediately spoke of his own original vow, and further praised all the ascetics, saying:
Virtuous immortals!

Now you have attained unobstructed eloquence, and your bodies have long practiced in accordance with the Dharma. Because your inner minds are pure, you are able to give rise to a deeply respectful and mindful heart towards people you have never known before.
Now, if you wish to abandon them, it is like loving relatives, and you give rise to great sorrow.
Although this is the case, the Dharma you seek, virtuous ones, is for the sake of the fruits of rebirth in the heavens, but I do not agree with this.
I now wish to seek liberation, not to take on existence.
My intention and wishes are determined like this.
After my mind observes such characteristics, I see that the place where you dwell is not something I wish for, and I only want to return, and I only want to leave, these two are very far apart.
However, I am also not unhappy with this place, and I also do not hate others anymore, and I do not see the faults of others, and therefore I do not stay here and turn my back on this practice.
However, you all!
You all abide in the Dharma, following the words of the sages of the past, you have all attained the Dharma of the great sages.'
At that time, those sages saw that the Bodhisattva's pursuit of liberation was supreme, and they gave rise to thoughts of sincere love and respect for the Bodhisattva.

At that time, there was a brahman sage in the assembly who always lay in ashes or on roof beams, wearing a corpse and rags, with blue and yellow ears and eyes, a long nose, and a white body, holding a water pot in his hand.
Having heard the Bodhisattva speak these words, he turned to the Bodhisattva's face, joyfully responding and praising the Bodhisattva, saying:
Your words are extremely subtle and wonderful, with the highest vow.

You are now able, in your youth before experiencing the five desires, to see their faults. If you are not thirsty for the desires of rebirth in the heavens, how could you know the faults of the heavens? Having observed this, you seek liberation. That person will soon attain liberation.
If, sir, you have such an intention and are determined to seek that liberation, you should now quickly go forth.
Not far from here, there is a place where a sage resides, called Ri Chuan Zang. There is a sage named A La Luo. He has attained the eye of right wisdom and purity.
You can go to him and ask. You should hear the true path of practice.
